subsection_content:
Infected animals pass immature eggs in their feces. Eggs develop in fresh water and enter snails. Snails are the host and continue to go through the next stages of development. Snails lay eggs on plants and are eaten by herbivores and then transmitted to humans through food (uncooked meat of infected animals).
In addition, humans can also directly introduce parasites into the body when eating raw vegetables contaminated with tapeworm larvae that have not been washed or cooked. After entering the human body, live liver flukes develop into adult flukes.
subsection_title: benh san la gan.json. Transmission routes of liver flukes
subsection_data:
benh san la gan.json. Transmission routes of liver flukes
Infected animals pass immature eggs in their feces. Eggs develop in fresh water and enter snails. Snails are the host and continue to go through the next stages of development. Snails lay eggs on plants and are eaten by herbivores and then transmitted to humans through food (uncooked meat of infected animals).
In addition, humans can also directly introduce parasites into the body when eating raw vegetables contaminated with tapeworm larvae that have not been washed or cooked. After entering the human body, live liver flukes develop into adult flukes.
